section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do during the day and at night?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Bear wants to give the moon a birthday present, if he can just find out what the moon wants. One night, Bear visits the moon. Their conversation may surprise you!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | Week 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Draw out children’s knowledge of the moon: whether it’s living or not; its shape and size; how near or far from Earth it is; etc.
Invite children to dance to the PreK on My Way™ theme music to build excitement for learning about what happens during day and night on Earth.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Happy Birthday, Moon by Frank Asch.
Happy Birthday, Moon is a narrative. Narratives are stories that often start with a problem. Scout enjoys reading about how Bear deals with a problem.
There is a question I want you think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why did Bear go on a long trip?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A fun part of reading this book is noticing where Bear and the moon are on different pages. We will listen for and use words that tell us where things are.
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Bear want to give to the moon?
Why does Bear climb the tree?
The book says that Bear’s voice echoed off a mountain.
Let’s pretend there’s an echo in this room. Echo back what I say: Hello, friends!
Who does Bear think he is hearing? Why is he excited?
Bear empties out his piggy bank. What is inside? Give me a thumbs up or down if you keep money in a piggy bank, or something like it, at home.
The hat is in the tree. It looks like the moon is behind the tree. In and behind tell us where things are. What word tells us where the moon is in the last picture on these pages?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why did Bear go on a long trip?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children to share:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He wanted to chat with the moon.
He wanted to know the moon’s birthday.
He wanted to find out what the moon wanted for his birthday.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about things we do in the day and things we do at night.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Bear go to chat with the moon or hide from the moon?
Bear goes to ch______ (chat) with the moon.
Bear goes to chat with the moon.
What are some of the places Bear went on his trip?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children’s knowledge of the world makes a big impact on their read-aloud comprehension. Spend time before reading to introduce important concepts to children. For example, if they understand that the moon is very big, very far away, and not living, they will understand something that Bear does not, and they’ll feel very smart, too!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | Week 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Express Pride
section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to discuss some of the new things they can do that make them proud. Ask children why they wanted to be able to do these things. Encourage children to explain how they learned their new skills. Explain that when we achieve something we feel good about or are proud of, we can talk about it to other people.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the express pride Mind Builder as we revisit the book Happy Birthday, Moon by Frank Asch.
Clifford likes to feel proud. Right now he feels proud because he is reading a book!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice whether we see Bear express pride in his accomplishments.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s review what Bear decides to do. What is it?
There’s a word for something you decide to do. The word is goal.
So, now Bear has a goal. Right away, he has a problem to solve. What is it?
Where did Bear start? Where is he now? Did he work hard to get here?
How do you think Bear felt after he gave the moon the hat? Do you think he feels proud about finding a birthday gift for the moon? (MB)
How do you feel when you are close to reaching a goal? Show me what proud looks like. (MB)
How do you think Bear is feeling before he talks to the moon? How about after?

section.rac_body-text: Help children understand how good it feels to persist together as a team to reach a goal. Do the hula-hoop passing game. Drape a hula-hoop on one child’s arm, then have all children join hands in a circle. (You may prefer to do this in two or three smaller groups.) Have children work together to move the hoop all the way around the circle without breaking the chain. Lead the children in a big cheer when they reach their goal!
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about their goals.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Developing self-esteem can be hard for some children. Guide them into seeing the good in their accomplishments by giving specific praise and asking questions that help them see what they succeeded in. Sometimes a simple “You should be proud” is enough prodding to help build their self-esteem. (Emmons, n.d.)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | Week 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children how talking about the moon on Day 1 helped them understand the book.
Learn the words to “Happy Birthday” and moon in the home languages of your multilingual learners. Then sing the song in English and the other language(s).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Happy Birthday, Moon by Frank Asch.
Scout loves Happy Birthday, Moon because he loves reading narratives about birthdays.
This is the question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How is the moon in the story like the real moon?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on Using Background Knowledge
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions. Have conversations with children to help them explain how they use their background knowledge to understand the story.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at these four pictures. Are they all the same? What changes? Does the real moon move across the sky at night?
Bear wants to chat with the moon.
Does the moon talk back? Why or why not?
Bear watches the moon move closer to the hat in the tree. Then he says that the hat “fits.”
Why does Bear think that? Could Bear be right?
Why does Bear think he has to go back to the mountain to talk with the moon again? What does he tell the moon?
When the moon looks like a big bright circle, we call it a full moon. When have you seen a full moon in the night sky?
Did you use background knowledge as we read the story today? Let’s see as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How is the moon in the story like the real moon?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:

Share a pen with children as you work together to write about things we do in the day and night. Have them practice using prepositions to tell where they are in the day and night. Model using end punctuation for sentences.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the moon in the story and the real moon do in the sky?
The moon m_____ (moves) across the sky.
The moon moves across the sky.
Does the real moon always have the same round shape or does it change?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Sharing birthday songs in different languages teaches all students the richness of world languages and the universality of birthday traditions. If children are shy about sharing birthday songs in their home languages, try enlisting the aid of parents or community members. You could even look for and play clips posted online.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | Week 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children all they have learned about Earth this week. What have they learned about daytime and nighttime? What is their favorite time of day?
Invite children to sing “The Bear Went Over the Mountain.” On mountain, have them make the shape with their arms, and on see, have them shade their eyes.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Daytime Nighttime. It is a poster with lots of colorful pictures.
Scout loves posters with narrative writing on them because they come from the writer’s imagination!
Happy Birthday, Moon and Daytime Nighttime both talk about things that happen at night. Let’s see if we find any connections between the two!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
What do we do during the day and at night?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Day and Night
section.rac_body-text: Use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This poster is called Daytime Nighttime. What small word do you hear in both of these words?
What’s different in the daytime and nighttime pictures of the mountains?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 14 of Happy Birthday, Moon.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do the mountains at night on the poster look like the mountain that Bear climbed at night?
What is different in these pictures of day and night in the country? What is the same?
What is the mother pushing? Who can point to the place on this poster that is the most like where we live?

section.rac_body-text: Have children draw daytime/nighttime pictures about other places—their bedroom, a park, the beach, or a farm, for example.

Provide a writing prompt about things we do in the day and at night and have children draw and write in response to the prompt. Encourage children who are writing to add a period at the end of a sentence.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The Day 4 lessons are a great opportunity for children to make cross-text connections. However, helping children connect what they’re reading today to books they’ve read before can be a part of any read-aloud experience. Helping children connect texts improves overall comprehension and is one more way you can converse with children as you read.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | Week 1: Day and Night

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out things they do every day and every night. Encourage them to describe in words the actions they are dramatizing.
Give children another opportunity to sing “Happy Birthday” in the home language of some of your students, and share the word for moon in that language as well.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Happy Birthday, Moon.
This book is a narrative. Scout enjoys narratives because he likes to find out what characters do.
We’ve read about Bear trying to give the moon a birthday present. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Would you like to give the moon a birthday present? Why?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The moon did not reply to Bear Why did Bear think the moon did not reply?
Now I’ll be Bear, and you all echo, or repeat, what I say. Ready?
section.rac_body-text: After reading Bear’s lines, wait for children to repeat the lines.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Bear think the moon wants a hat for his birthday?
Pretend you are looking up and telling the moon what you want for your birthday.
Show me how Bear felt when he found the hat. Did he look excited?
Why do you think Bear felt this way?
Now I’ll be Bear again, and you all echo what I say. Ready?
section.rac_body-text: After reading Bear’s lines, wait for children to “echo” the lines.
Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Would you like to give the moon a birthday present? Why?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Yes, because the moon is beautiful.
No, because the moon is not a person.
No, because it would be too hard to do.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or talk about things they do during the day and at night using at least one sentence that has more than four words. Then invite them to share their work with the class.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why would you like to give the moon a present?
What do you think the moon would like for a present?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers begin to string together longer sentences with more detail. For example, a 4-year-old might combine two related sentences into one like, “Bear paddled his boat and hiked through the woods.” Encourage children to express the bigger ideas developing in their minds by providing frames, such as, “First Bear___, then Bear___ .”
